title: Thesis/Claim
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

Except where otherwise noted, each point of the rubric is earned independently; for example, a student could earn a point for evidence without earning a point for thesis/claim.

To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt; it should not simply restate or rephrase the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions:
The response does not respond to the prompt with a defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following:

  • “In the twentieth century, a wide range of people developed critiques of colonialism to promote independence movements in Africa and equality in the United States.”

  • “In the twentieth century, people in the African diaspora developed critiques of colonialism in response to racism and discrimination.”

  • “In the twentieth century, African Americans criticized colonialism to support independence movements in Africa.”

Examples that do not earn this point:

  • Provide a restatement of the prompt

  • Provide a defensible claim but do not establish a line of reasoning

  • Establish a line of reasoning but do not provide a defensible claim

The response does respond to the prompt with a defensible thesis or claim that establishes a line of reasoning about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

title: Context
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must describe broader events, developments, processes, or disciplinary connections that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. The point is not earned for a passing phrase or reference.
descriptions:
The response does not describe a broader historical or disciplinary context relevant to why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples of relevant context that earn this point include the following, if appropriate elaboration is provided:

  • “As early as the sixteenth century, European powers began establishing colonies in Africa, including the Portuguese along the Swahili Coast. With time, Europeans colonized much of Africa.”

  • “The Black Freedom movement was a period of international activism in the mid-twentieth century. It included the Civil Rights movement and the Black Power movement, which heightened Black consciousness and racial pride in the United States and abroad.”

  • “After World War I, President Wilson’s goal of self-determination was applied only to Europe. In other parts of the world, colonies were transferred from the losers to the winners. After World War II, peoples around the world began to demand their independence, asserting their right to govern themselves.”

Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Provide an overgeneralized statement

  • Provide context that is not relevant to the prompt

  • Provide a passing phrase or reference

The response describes a broader historical or disciplinary context relevant to why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples of relevant context that earn this point include the following, if appropriate elaboration is provided:

  • “As early as the sixteenth century, European powers began establishing colonies in Africa, including the Portuguese along the Swahili Coast. With time, Europeans colonized much of Africa.”

  • “The Black Freedom movement was a period of international activism in the mid-twentieth century. It included the Civil Rights movement and the Black Power movement, which heightened Black consciousness and racial pride in the United States and abroad.”

  • “After World War I, President Wilson’s goal of self-determination was applied only to Europe. In other parts of the world, colonies were transferred from the losers to the winners. After World War II, peoples around the world began to demand their independence, asserting their right to govern themselves.”

title: Evidence from the Sources
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

To earn one point, the response must accurately describe—rather than simply quote—the content from at least two sources.

To earn two points, the response must accurately describe—rather than just quote—the content from at least three sources to support an argument in response to the prompt.
descriptions:
The response does not meet the criteria for points.

Responses that earn 1 point:

  • Use the content of at least two sources to address why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century

Responses that earn 2 points:

  • Support an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century by accurately using the content of at least three sources

Responses that earn 0 points:

  • Use evidence from fewer than two of the sources

  • Misinterpret the content of the sources

  • Quote the content of the sources without providing an accompanying description

  • Address sources collectively rather than considering the content of each source separately
The response uses the content of at least two sources to address why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.
The response supports an argument in response to the prompt by accurately using the content of at least three sources.

title: Evidence Beyond Sources
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must describe the evidence using more than a phrase or reference. This additional piece of evidence must be relevant to an argument in response to the prompt.
descriptions:
The response does not use at least one additional piece of specific evidence (beyond the evidence found in the sources) relevant to an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples of specific and relevant evidence beyond the sources that earn this point include the following, if appropriate elaboration is provided:

  • Jessie Redmon Fauset

  • Maya Angelou’s travel to Ghana

  • Pauli Murray’s travel to Ghana

  • W.E.B. Du Bois

  • Gwendolyn Bennett’s poetry

  • Countee Cullen’s poetry

  • The United Negro Improvement Association

  • 1960 as the Year of Africa

  • Negrismo

  • Les Fétiches by Loïs Mailou Jones

  • The Jungle (La Jungla) by Wifredo Lam

  • Joe Louis’s travel to Cuba

  • Malcolm X’s travel to Ghana

  • “Address to the Second UNIA Convention” by Marcus Garvey

Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Provide evidence that is not relevant to an argument about the prompt

  • Provide evidence that is outside the topic specified in the prompt

  • Repeat information that is specified in the prompt or in any of the sources

  • Provide a passing phrase or reference

The response uses at least one additional piece of specific evidence (beyond the evidence found in the sources) relevant to an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples of specific and relevant evidence beyond the sources that earn this point include the following, if appropriate elaboration is provided:

  • Jessie Redmon Fauset

  • Maya Angelou’s travel to Ghana

  • Pauli Murray’s travel to Ghana

  • W.E.B. Du Bois

  • Gwendolyn Bennett’s poetry

  • Countee Cullen’s poetry

  • The United Negro Improvement Association

  • 1960 as the Year of Africa

  • Negrismo

  • Les Fétiches by Loïs Mailou Jones

  • The Jungle (La Jungla) by Wifredo Lam

  • Joe Louis’s travel to Cuba

  • Malcolm X’s travel to Ghana

  • “Address to the Second UNIA Convention” by Marcus Garvey

Examples of acceptable use of an additional piece of specific historical evidence:

  • “Gwendolyn Bennett and Countee Cullen, major writers of the Harlem Renaissance, responded to colonialism by expressing their connection to African culture.”

  • “Malcolm X traveled to Ghana and linked his ideas about Black nationalism to African nationalism.”

title: Source Use
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must explain how or why (rather than simply identify) the perspective, purpose, context, or audience of each source (for at least two sources) is relevant to an argument about the prompt.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how or why the perspective, purpose, context, and/or audience of at least two sources is relevant to an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of an author’s perspective:

  • Source 3: “Aimé Césaire, a leader in the Négritude movement, was from Martinique in the Caribbean. He is an example of how widespread anti-colonial ideas became in the diaspora.”

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the author’s purpose:

  • Source 2: “Kwame Nkrumah had two clear purposes: to try and convince colonizing powers to grant independence to African countries and to persuade African countries to work together to support each other; this demonstrates how anti-colonial ideas were linked with ideas about Black unity.”

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the context of a source:

  • Source 4: “Martin Luther King Jr. was interviewed in Ghana while massive white resistance to the Brown vs. Board of Education decision was taking place across the American South, demonstrating how the American critique of colonialism emerged during the fight for Civil Rights at home.”

Example of acceptable explanation of the relevance of the audience:

  • Source 1: “Garvey directs his words to African Americans and calls for racial pride. This call for pride became increasingly widespread in African American communities and contributed to calls for African independence.”

Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Explain sourcing for fewer than two of the sources

  • Identify the perspective, purpose, context, and/or audience but fail to explain how or why it is relevant to an argument

  • Summarize the content or argument of the source without explaining the relevance of this summary to the perspective, purpose, context, and/or audience

The response explains how or why the perspective, purpose, context, and/or audience of at least two sources is relevant to an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

title: Reasoning
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria and examples or to score the response.

To earn this point, the response must demonstrate the use of reasoning to frame or structure an argument, even if the reasoning is uneven or the evidence lacks specificity.
descriptions:
The response does not use reasoning (e.g., causation, comparison, change, or continuity across time or geography) to set up an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples of using reasoning to set up an argument might include the following:

  • Analyzing the reasons for why these critiques developed in the twentieth century, considering both global developments after the two world wars and the domestic fight against Jim Crow (Addresses causation)

  • Analyzing the extent of change and continuity in why these critiques developed and how they changed throughout the century (Addresses continuity and change)

  • Comparing the arguments made against colonialism by American and world leaders (Utilizes comparison)

The response uses reasoning (e.g., causation, comparison, change or continuity across time or geography) to set up an argument about why critiques of colonialism developed across the diaspora in the twentieth century.

Examples of using reasoning to set up an argument might include the following:

  • Analyzing the extent of change and continuity in why these critiques developed and how they changed throughout the century (Addresses continuity and change)

  • Comparing the arguments made against colonialism by American and world leaders (Utilizes comparison)
